In my console I have this stack trace:

 An exception occurred while performing WSDL XML conformance validation for file file:///Users/sam/Documents/workspace/ticsWs/main/workArea/src/webContent/wsdl/TICS.wsdl.
!STACK 0
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.validation.internal.xml.DefaultXMLValidator.run(DefaultXMLValidator.java:139)

	at org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.validation.core.AbstractNestedValidator.validate(AbstractNestedValidator.java:242)
	at org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.validation.core.AbstractNestedValidator.validateInJob(AbstractNestedValidator.java:93)
	at org.eclipse.wst.validation.internal.delegates.DelegatingValidator.validateInJob(DelegatingValidator.java:249)

Can you tell me what version of WTP you're using and with which JRE you're running Eclipse?

It is wtp 1.5.0.

I'm using JRE 1.5.0.

Mac OS X version 10.4.7.
Is this still a problem? If yes, can you try newer WTP versions - 1.5.4 or 2.0?

The problem seems to be that the DONE flag is not set on the marker anymore and that controls the menu contribution. The code that used to set the flag in org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.validation.core.AbstractNestedValidator.createMarkers(IFile, ValidationMessage[], IReporter) is not able to do it because the markers are not created yet. The markers are not created right away anynmore because the validator is running in a job. The validation framework message reporter is caching the messages and only creates the markers when the validator finishes.
Opps, wrong bug - please ignore the previous comment.
Sam, was there another exception in the log nearby with the text "Error creating XML reader for WSDL XML conformance validation."?
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991
I wasn't able to reproduce this when validating a newly created or imported .wsdl file.  Sam, could you attach the one that's giving you problems to this bug if it is still a problem with 1.5.4?
I am going to resolve as worksforme for now. Please re-open with more details if it's still an issue.
